Kangasniemi&quot;,&quot;J. Lammintakanen&quot;,&quot;A. H\u00e4ggman-Laitila&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2021,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of advanced nursing&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/towards-remote-leadership-health-care-lessons-learned-terkamomoisio/0ec929cb11d25eb0be5fc90bffe26b60/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1111/jan.15028&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:10},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;A Qualitative Study on Developing IT Strategies for The Effective Remote Work Using IT Balanced Scorecard&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This Remote work has become increasingly prevalent among many companies, even as the COVID-19 pandemic gradually recedes. However, effective planning is crucial for ensuring the successful implementation of remote work in the long run. One practical approach to remote work planning involves using an IT Balanced Scorecard. The IT Balanced Scorecard serves as a framework that enables organizations to align their overall business objectives and actions with their IT strategies, focusing on four distinct perspectives: customer, financial, internal processes, and learning and growth. In this research conducted a qualitative study and identified the advantages and disadvantages of working from the office and remote work. We also gathered insights on the technological tools, essential qualities required for effective remote work, and etiquette guidelines to foster healthy workplace interactions\u2014an important consideration for organizations. Based on our findings and leveraging the IT Balanced Scorecard, we have developed a set of objectives and activities to mitigate the disadvantages associated with remote working. By employing an IT Strategy developed through the four perspectives of the Balanced Scorecard - namely customer, finance, internal processes, and learning &amp; growth. it is anticipated that this IT Strategy can assist organizations in effectively initiating and optimizing remote work implementation which organizations could refer to when seeking to optimize their remote work arrangements.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Glenny Chudra&quot;,&quot;A. Yohannis&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2023,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;2023 International Conference on Networking, Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, and Technology (IConNECT)&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/study-developing-strategies-effective-remote-work-using-chudra/01b1ba06d63b5633badd51e90724cf9a/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1109/IConNECT56593.2023.10327330&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;196-201&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:11},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Multi-Process Logistics Planning for Cost Minimization and Workload Balance in Steel Production Systems&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Logistics planning is a key to the coordination of multiple processes in steel production systems. This work investigates a new and practical bi-objective logistics planning problem arising from steelmaking-hot rolling-cold rolling processes. Its first objective is to minimize the sum of fixed costs, transportation costs, out-of-stock penalties, and inventory costs. The second one is to balance the workload of parallel machines. A mixed integer linear program is formulated for the concerned problem. To solve it, a genetic algorithm is problem-specifically designed. In it, the concerned bi-objective optimization problem is first transformed into a single-objective one by weighting two objective functions. Then, Pareto solutions are obtained through the presented algorithm by adjusting the weighted coefficients. Experimental results obtained by the presented algorithm are compared with those obtained by solving the mixed integer linear program with CPLEX. Its great performance is verified, thus showing its readiness to be applied in practice.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Zhuohan Zhang&quot;,&quot;Ziyan Zhao&quot;,&quot;Yang Zhang&quot;,&quot;Shixin Liu&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2022,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;2022 IEEE International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/multiprocess-logistics-planning-cost-minimization-zhang/6dc5c2dbcfaf5110b7558459270b98c4/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1109/ICNSC55942.2022.10004178&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1-6&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:12},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Robust optimization for relief logistics planning under uncertainties in demand and transportation time&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract Emergency logistics is an essential component of post-disaster relief campaigns. However, there are always various uncertainties when making decisions related to planning and implementing post-disaster relief logistics. Considering the particular environmental conditions during post-disaster relief after a catastrophic earthquake in a mountainous area, this paper proposes a stochastic model for post-disaster relief logistics to guide the tactical design for mobilizing relief supply levels, planning initial helicopter deployments, and creating transportation plans within the disaster region, given the uncertainties in demand and transportation time. We then introduce a robust optimization approach to cope with these uncertainties and deduce the robust counterpart of the proposed stochastic model. A numerical example based on disaster logistics during the Great Sichuan Earthquake demonstrates that the model can help post-disaster managers to determine the initial deployments of emergency resources. Sensitivity analyses explore the trade-off between optimization and robustness by varying the robust optimization parameter values.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Yajie Liu&quot;,&quot;Hongtao Lei&quot;,&quot;Dezhi Zhang&quot;,&quot;Wu Zhiyong&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2018,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Applied Mathematical Modelling&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/optimization-relief-logistics-planning-uncertainties-liu/bd27f76720265aaab4006161fea79e9c/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/J.APM.2017.10.041&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;55&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;262-280&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:13},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Short-term logistics management at a multinational corporation&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract Nowadays, many companies still operate without any process standardization in relation to short-term logistics management, which leads to a lack of control of both times and costs of logistical operations. This paper starts from a study that has been performed at a multinational corporation which manufactures fiber-reinforced plastic boxes and cabinets with doors, where the final product-storage area and the picking section frequently become overloaded. In addition, warehouse operators do not follow standardized procedures and usually carry out too many movements to complete their tasks. Finally, there is not a suitable daily logistics planning system to make sure that capacity and demand are in balance. This paper proposes a solution to this problem by means of a Methods-Time Measurement (MTM) study as well as a daily workload planner to control short-term logistical operations. Thanks to the implementation of this system, the company has been able to plan the day-to-day workload in an accurate way and to precisely determine the necessary resources for the picking and shipping orders. Moreover, the company has gained flexibility in order to better match demand and capacity and has experimented significant cost savings and a better delivery service to its customers.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Esther Alvarez de los Mozos&quot;,&quot;Nicolas Lopez&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2020,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Procedia Manufacturing&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/shortterm-logistics-management-corporation-mozos/bc36ff26221c56448bddab1111d09620/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.promfg.2020.10.236&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;51&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1696-1702&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:14},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Employee welfare: Developing change strategies to address empathy burnout in caring professions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The general health and wellbeing of an organisation\u2019s workforce, also referred to as employee welfare, remains a crucial component in organisational and leadership planning. At the level of an individual, welfare is often related to one\u2019s level of satisfaction, engagement and dedication. At the organisational level, welfare can be associated with productivity, turnover, and employee relationships. An employee\u2019s welfare, particularly in a caring profession, is often subject to the emotionally demanding needs of their patients, which significantly affects their ability to remain empathic and compassionate towards others, and themselves. Empathy, like any emotional resource, can be exhausted if not replenished often. Compassion fatigue, also known as empathy burnout, is an emotional state experienced by those working in emotionally demanding roles, such as healthcare professionals, police service and social workers. The common symptoms of empathy burnout include depression, anxiety, absenteeism and lethargy. At an organisational level, it is imperative that leadership decisions consider the implications of their profession to the wider workforce, and so develop strategies to prevent empathy burnout. This paper explored the perspectives of employee welfare at a local hospital to develop strategies for change that may assist caring professionals in managing their stress and maintaining levels of empathy. From the exploratory research project, strategies emerged that could be actioned to improve employee welfare across the organisation. These strategies for change included strengthening communication lines to eliminate barriers to support, bolstering the existing employee assistance programme, developing resilience training schemes, and closing the gap between executive leadership and staff. Caring professions are positions/roles including but not limited to nursing, clinicians, physicians, paramedics, mental health employee, caregiving, counsellors, physiologists, orderly and welfare officers.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Turner&quot;,&quot;Lesley Gill&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2019,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Scope: Contemporary Research Topics (Flexible Learning 4)&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/employee-welfare-developing-change-strategies-address-turner/8fa41cbad0ce52ac9a6ec1f0fa0f23bf/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.34074/scop.5004013&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;A Co-Occurrence Scrutiny of Transformational Leadership, Employee Engagement, Well-Being and Burnout via a Bibliometric Analysis&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract In the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, employees anticipate that their leaders will demonstrate greater empathy for the unexpected issues in the workplace. According to recent studies, the present and future require leadership to reimagine human resources leadership and the entire employee experience by focusing on people, cooperation, tight communication, and reestablishing connection and trust. In their 2021 report on the future of work after Covid-19, McKinsey Global Institute notes that hybrid remote work could continue to address the fact that 20 to 25 percent of workers in advanced economies and around 10 percent in emerging economies could work from home three to five days a week, primarily in computer-based office work, including offices of all sizes and corporate headquarters. In this light, the purpose of this research to provide an overview of the relationships between the leadership style, employee engagement, as well as their wellbeing versus burnout. The paper intends to propose a bibliographic analysis of the scientific articles simultaneously tackling the main envisaged constructs, respectively leadership, engagement, well-being and burnout. Given the fact that the inclusion of the Covid-19 pandemic would have narrowed down too much the analysis, the term was not considered in the searches. The bibliometric analysis was performed by means of VOSviewer.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Elena-M\u0103d\u0103lina V\u0103t\u0103m\u0103nescu&quot;,&quot;Florina Vintil\u0103&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2023,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Proceedings of the International Conference on Business Excellence&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/cooccurrence-scrutiny-transformational-leadership-v\u0103t\u0103m\u0103nescu/037d4fb9f27d51b28793f70da52d8376/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2478/picbe-2023-0117&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;17&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1306 - 1318&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;ORGANIZATIONAL AND ECONOMIC CONDITIONS FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF LOGISTICS NETWORK&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The article is devoted to study and development of a formalized model of organizational and economic conditions to ensure effective management of logistics functions. The author determined that logistics functions are realized through the prism of logistics operations, which are divided into external and internal. It is noted that internal logistics operations are carried out under the influence of internal organizational and economic conditions (efficiency of customs in documentation, trade and transport infrastructure, ease of organization of international shipments, competence and quality of logistics services, the ability to track goods, the frequency with which goods arrive at recipients). scheduled or expected delivery time). The application of the logistics approach involves the creation of appropriate organizational conditions.\\nThe concept of logistics is a system of approaches to streamlining economic activity by optimizing flow processes. It is defined by managers as an effective motivational approach to management in order to reduce production costs. This concept becomes the basis of the company&#x27;s economic strategy: logistics is used as a tool of competition and is seen as management logic for the implementation of the plan, distribution and control of financial and human resources. This approach ensures close coordination of logistics and production strategy. Effective management of logistics functions includes the flow of goods and services. It covers an ordered sequence of steps from the procurement of raw materials to the finished product, so that it provides value to the customer. Logistics management allows you to establish strong communications and supplier relationships, helping to avoid shipment delays and minimize logistical errors. Efficient logistics provides the best bargaining power to get the best prices and goods in the shortest possible time. During the production processes and execution of orders, logistics managers need to ensure the efficiency of material flow. Optimizing the flow of goods allows you to reduce the delay of goods in the warehouse, minimize transportation costs and ensure the preservation of stocks. By balancing capital investment, maintaining the required level of service and taking into account the variability of supply and demand, companies can significantly improve inventory turnover, service level and significantly reduce costs.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Volodymyr Kolodiychyk&quot;,&quot;Zoriana Krypka&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2021,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Herald UNU. Millennials, on the cusp of embarking on important leadership roles in this new remote work environment, pose challenges and opportunities for organizations will that will last long after the pandemic.\\n\\n\\nDesign/methodology/approach\\nThis paper provides a viewpoint based on a narrative review and on the authors\u2019 professional experiences within organizations. Based upon these findings, this paper has reimagined the Mumford skills model to explore millennial managers in this new remote work, post-pandemic context. The goal of this narrative review was to provide a full picture of the \u201cMillennial manager\u201d and the challenges they face in becoming effective managers, as well as highlight the important strengths they bring to the table.\\n\\n\\nFindings\\nManagers may have challenges regarding job satisfaction, productivity and organizational commitment. The positive factors are millennials prefer flexibility, teamwork and creating a positive work-life balance. The negative side has to do with isolation and the ability to embrace the organization culture in a remote environment. This model shows positive and limiting factors of millennials related to organization effectiveness. The major propositions and model were that millennium managers in this new environment increase interpersonal communication to maintain trust, effective mentoring, resolve strong organizational culture and ensure effective delegation and conflict resolution.\\n\\n\\nPractical implications\\nThis study discovered challenges for managers, including developing loyalty and improving employee job satisfaction and organizational commitment. Active listening is necessary for team management to show that all team members are valued irrespective of the work environment. Active listening and empathy will increase social support at work, which improves personal well-being and productivity. Millennials will continue to use their technological skills, their desire for teamwork and their preference for participative management, resulting in becoming an invaluable asset in this era of organizational transformation. The challenge for organizations is to realize the millennial generation possesses many talents and must successfully engage them in the pursuit of organizational goals.\\n\\n\\nOriginality/value\\nThis paper adds to the body of knowledge regarding millennials in organizations with a specific focus on the new work environment created by the global pandemic. The authors hope that their adapted skills model \u2013 the millennial manager skills model \u2013 becomes an important resource for articulation this new environment that millennial managers are in and that this model can be further refined and expanded through empirical exploration.\\n&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Kerri M. Bushardt&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2022,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Management Research Review&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/manager-skills-model-work-environment-camp/c74e52b8746d5d50bdb398c0131846a8/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1108/mrr-01-2021-0076&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:18},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;A Military Logistics Network Planning System&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This paper presents a proof of concept for a Military Logistics Network Planning System (MLNPS) to be used during mission planning to quickly identify a robust logistical footprint that can adequately sustain units deployed in an expeditionary environment. The logistical network is modeled using an efficient form of goal-seeking deterministic discrete event simulation to process supply requisitions through the logistical network. The queuing information obtained from the simulation informs capacity adjustments to the network to maximize efficiency. This process of simulation and network tuning continues interactively until an adequate and robust logistical footprint is found. During the planning stages, the MLNPS can be used to identify and mitigate logistical problems instead of waiting to react to backlogs when the military&#x27;s operations would have already been affected. Designed to run as an app on the Army&#x27;s enterprise resource planning (ERP) system (Global Combat Support System-Army), the MLNPS can also be used during operations to inform commanders of expected operational impacts on logistics. Commitment: Leaders must be committed to their role and their team, consistently showing dedication to achieving objectives.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;2. Connection: Building strong relationships through empathy, dialogue, and mindfulness to foster a sense of trust and belonging.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;3. Communication: Mastering all forms of communication (synchronous, asynchronous, verbal, written) and balancing engagement without micromanaging.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n\r\n    &lt;h2&gt;Leadership Philosophy&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;The Remote Leadership Codex is grounded in the philosophy of influence over control, with leaders acting as facilitators who guide their teams toward success.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;This philosophy embraces: &lt;/p&gt;\r\n    &lt;ul&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Mindfulness: Leaders should be present and understanding, managing both personal and team-level needs.&lt;/li&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Continuous Improvement: Leadership is a continuous process of refining operations and workflows to meet team and organizational goals.&lt;/li&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Situational Leadership: Leaders should adapt their approach to each employee, providing the right level of support and autonomy.&lt;/li&gt;\r\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\r\n\r\n    &lt;h2&gt;Module 1: Commitment \u2013 Leading by Example&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;This module highlights the need for leaders to show dedication by leading through action. Commitment is about setting the tone for your team, \r\n    especially in remote environments. Leaders should be mindful of their own consistency and reliability, setting expectations for their team.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;Core Themes: &lt;/p&gt;\r\n    &lt;ul&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Holistic Leadership and Mindfulness&lt;/li&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Influence Over Control&lt;/li&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Continuous Improvement of both personal and operational workflows&lt;/li&gt;\r\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\r\n\r\n    &lt;h2&gt;Module 2: Connection \u2013 Building Relationships Through Mindfulness&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;Remote leaders must prioritize building strong connections within their teams, especially in virtual environments where isolation can occur. \r\n    This module focuses on fostering empathy, dialogue, and situational leadership. Building connections is not just about work\u2014it\u2019s about recognizing each team member&#x27;s individual needs.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;Core Themes: &lt;/p&gt;\r\n    &lt;ul&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Empathy and Dialogue&lt;/li&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Situational Leadership (tailoring leadership to the individual\u2019s needs and development stage)&lt;/li&gt;\r\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\r\n\r\n    &lt;h2&gt;Module 3: Communication \u2013 Mastering All Forms&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;Effective communication is critical to successful remote leadership. Leaders must be adept at using different communication styles depending on the context\u2014whether it&#x27;s for quick updates or in-depth discussions. \r\n    This module focuses on balancing synchronous (live) and asynchronous (written) communication to maintain team engagement without micromanagement.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;Core Themes: &lt;/p&gt;\r\n    &lt;ul&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Tailored Communication&lt;/li&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Mindful Listening and Adaptation&lt;/li&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Avoiding Micromanagement by using metrics to guide communication strategies&lt;/li&gt;\r\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\r\n\r\n    &lt;h2&gt;Life Happens \u2013 Managing Crises and the Unexpected (Partially Outlined)&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;This module focuses on how leaders can prepare for and manage interruptions and crises that impact team members. \r\n    It emphasizes balancing empathy with logistical planning to support team members through both minor and major disruptions. \r\n    This section is still being outlined and will include practical steps for proactively managing team disruptions while maintaining team performance.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n\r\n    &lt;p&gt;Key Elements: &lt;/p&gt;\r\n    &lt;ul&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Proactive planning, including contingency frameworks and risk mitigation strategies&lt;/li&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Using performance metrics to avoid micromanagement and offer support where needed&lt;/li&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Balancing individual well-being with collective team success&lt;/li&gt;\r\n        &lt;li&gt;Empathy, support, and understanding, recognizing that life happens even for the most dedicated employees&lt;/li&gt;\r\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\r\n\r\n    &lt;h2&gt;Modules in Development&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n    &lt;p&gt;Some modules are still under development. Commitment: Leaders must be committed to their role and their team, consistently showing dedication to achieving objectives.&lt;/p&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;2. Connection: Building strong relationships through empathy, dialogue, and mindfulness to foster a sense of trust and belonging.&lt;/p&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;3. Communication: Mastering all forms of communication (synchronous, asynchronous, verbal, written) and balancing engagement without micromanaging.&lt;/p&gt;\n\n    &lt;h2&gt;Leadership Philosophy&lt;/h2&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;The Remote Leadership Codex is grounded in the philosophy of influence over control, with leaders acting as facilitators who guide their teams toward success.&lt;/p&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;This philosophy embraces: &lt;/p&gt;\n    &lt;ul&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Mindfulness: Leaders should be present and understanding, managing both personal and team-level needs.&lt;/li&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Continuous Improvement: Leadership is a continuous process of refining operations and workflows to meet team and organizational goals.&lt;/li&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Situational Leadership: Leaders should adapt their approach to each employee, providing the right level of support and autonomy.&lt;/li&gt;\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\n\n    &lt;h2&gt;Module 1: Commitment \u2013 Leading by Example&lt;/h2&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;This module highlights the need for leaders to show dedication by leading through action. Commitment is about setting the tone for your team, \n    especially in remote environments. Leaders should be mindful of their own consistency and reliability, setting expectations for their team.&lt;/p&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;Core Themes: &lt;/p&gt;\n    &lt;ul&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Holistic Leadership and Mindfulness&lt;/li&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Influence Over Control&lt;/li&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Continuous Improvement of both personal and operational workflows&lt;/li&gt;\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\n\n    &lt;h2&gt;Module 2: Connection \u2013 Building Relationships Through Mindfulness&lt;/h2&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;Remote leaders must prioritize building strong connections within their teams, especially in virtual environments where isolation can occur. \n    This module focuses on fostering empathy, dialogue, and situational leadership. Building connections is not just about work\u2014it\u2019s about recognizing each team member&#x27;s individual needs.&lt;/p&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;Core Themes: &lt;/p&gt;\n    &lt;ul&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Empathy and Dialogue&lt;/li&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Situational Leadership (tailoring leadership to the individual\u2019s needs and development stage)&lt;/li&gt;\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\n\n    &lt;h2&gt;Module 3: Communication \u2013 Mastering All Forms&lt;/h2&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;Effective communication is critical to successful remote leadership. Leaders must be adept at using different communication styles depending on the context\u2014whether it&#x27;s for quick updates or in-depth discussions. \n    This module focuses on balancing synchronous (live) and asynchronous (written) communication to maintain team engagement without micromanagement.&lt;/p&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;Core Themes: &lt;/p&gt;\n    &lt;ul&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Tailored Communication&lt;/li&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Mindful Listening and Adaptation&lt;/li&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Avoiding Micromanagement by using metrics to guide communication strategies&lt;/li&gt;\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\n\n    &lt;h2&gt;Life Happens \u2013 Managing Crises and the Unexpected (Partially Outlined)&lt;/h2&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;This module focuses on how leaders can prepare for and manage interruptions and crises that impact team members. \n    It emphasizes balancing empathy with logistical planning to support team members through both minor and major disruptions. \n    This section is still being outlined and will include practical steps for proactively managing team disruptions while maintaining team performance.&lt;/p&gt;\n\n    &lt;p&gt;Key Elements: &lt;/p&gt;\n    &lt;ul&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Proactive planning, including contingency frameworks and risk mitigation strategies&lt;/li&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Using performance metrics to avoid micromanagement and offer support where needed&lt;/li&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Balancing individual well-being with collective team success&lt;/li&gt;\n        &lt;li&gt;Empathy, support, and understanding, recognizing that life happens even for the most dedicated employees&lt;/li&gt;\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\n\n    &lt;h2&gt;Modules in Development&lt;/h2&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;Some modules are still under development. It is typically found in the form of compounds in minerals. The most common aluminum-containing mineral is **bauxite**, which is the primary source for commercial aluminum production. Bauxite consists mainly of aluminum oxide minerals such as gibbsite, boehmite, and diaspore, and is found in soil and rock formations.\n\nAluminum is the third most abundant element in the Earth&#x27;s crust, but due to its high reactivity, it does not occur naturally as a free metal. {"role": "tool", "name": "browser", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1729797703.004449, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "https://www.ancient-origins.net/artifacts-ancient-technology/nanjing-belt-0018546", "domain": "www.ancient-origins.net", "text": "\n  * \u301074\u2020The Legacy of Armenia: Trade, Metallurgy, and Forging of Precious Metals of the Ancient World\u3011\n  * \u301075\u2020Bronze Urartian Belt Proves Kingdom Extended Much Further North\u3011\n\n[Image 18: Aluminium artifact found in a 3rd century Chinese tomb. (Soul-guidance)]\n\nAluminium artifact found in a 3rd century Chinese tomb. (\u301076\u2020Soul-guidance\u2020www.soul-guidance.com\u3011)\n\n## A Discovery That Defied Common Knowledge\n\nSoon after the stunning discovery, the Chinese scientific circles were stirred. Thorough analysis was required of all the metallic pieces discovered. The first tests were conducted by Nanjing University, and the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and they found that the tested pieces were an alloy containing mostly aluminum.\n\nSuch a claim caused a big shock, as everyone knew that aluminum is very difficult to isolate from bauxite, as a pure metal, without using a lot of electric power. Nevertheless, further tests were conducted, on other pieces as well, revealing that not all of them were from aluminum. Others were made from an alloy that contained mostly \u301077\u2020silver\u3011.\n\nBetween 1958 and 1959, the third round of tests was conducted at Qinghua University, where it was finally firmly concluded that the primary metal in the alloy was aluminum, with other fragments made from silver alloy.\n\nFrom this point on, there were other studies over the decades - many of which tried to change the narrative that was established early on. One theory stated that the aluminum belt parts were irregularly shaped, and could have been parts of modern aluminum tools that were left by potential grave robbers before the discovery was made. While it is possible that grave robbers entered the grave before the very first arrival of the archaeological team, it is not certain that anything of the sort occurred, or that they dropped aluminum fragments.\n\nSome sources claim that there were other similar belt buckles amongst other ancient Chinese relics, containing parts made from aluminum. They were never studied, however, and their presence remains unconfirmed. Either way, the Nanjing Belt left a deep whirlpool in the Chinese and global scholarly circles. It provided an enigma that was never fully resolved.\n\n  * \u301078\u2020More than Metal: Amazing Historical Suits of Armor\u3011\n  * \u301079\u2020UFO Wreckage? Ancient Metal Object Found in Romania Has Unexplained Origins\u3011\n\n## The Tomb Veiled in Mystery\n\nSadly, there isn\u2019t much more that is known about the Nanjing Belt or the discovery of the ancient hero\u2019s tomb. Popular sources are exceptionally vague on this topic - perhaps for a reason? Officially, the tomb of Zhou Chu is not mentioned. The mentions of this 1952 discovery are reserved only to the fringes of the online scholarly communities, and we cannot say why.\n\nPopularly, the writer Erich von D\u00e4niken, in his famed work \u201cChariots of the Gods\u201d, wrote of this discovery and claimed that the traces of aluminum alloy are a clear proof of \u301080\u2020ancient aliens\u3011 visiting Earth and sharing deep knowledge with ancient civilizations.\n\nCould such a thing be true? We do not know for certain. Could it, on the other hand, be possible that the ancient Chinese found a way to create an aluminum alloy through methods lost to history and the knowledge of man? If it is so, then there truly are deeper secrets hiding in the world\u2019s history.\n\nTop image: Left, ancient alchemy painting. Right, The artifact known as the \u2018Nanjing Belt\u2019 seems to be proof of the existence of aluminum in early China. Aluminium it will be remembered does not appear alone in nature. It took Europeans till the early nineteenth century to understand how to isolate this useful substance and even then the aluminium that issued was far from pure.\n\nChinese historians were, understandably, bemused and something of a civil war broke out, not helped by the fact that the Cultural Revolution was on the horizon. If there was a resolution though before Mao\u2019s guillotine came down it was that four pieces were, indeed, aluminium. The problem then was not metallurgical but rather archaeological: were they Jin Dynasty \u301013\u2020relics\u2020www.azed.gov\u3011 or had they been placed in the tomb in the nineteenth or twentieth centuries? If genuine, it goes without saying that you would need a merchant cash advance and possibly your life savings multiplied by three to get a sniff at these objects in an auction house.\n\nThis question was taken up in the west by three scholars \u2013 Butler, Glidewell and Pritchard \u2013 at St Andrew\u2019s University who looked at the question in\u00a0 \u2018Aluminium Objects from a Jin Dynasty Tomb \u2013 Can They Be Authentic?\u2019 Interdisciplinary Science Reviews 11 (1986), 88-94.\n\nThe abstract sums up their work nicely:\n\n&gt; Pieces of aluminium, supposedly parts of a set of belt ornaments, were found in a Jin dynasty (AD 265\u2013420) tomb during excavations in the 1950s. The authenticity of these finds was questioned at the time in view of the technology required to isolate aluminium from its ore. In this review the archaeological and analytical evidence is reconsidered, but the matter remains unsettled, as it is known, from experimental evidence, that aluminium alloys can be prepared by the carbon reduction of alumina. Examination of the thermodynamic data for this process in terms of Ellingham diagrams demonstrates unequivocally that the temperature required for this process is greatly in excess of that possible with Jin dynasty technology, and so the finds cannot be authentic. However, it is quite possible that metallic objects containing small quantities of aluminium could have been produced in China at that time. The review ends with some speculation on how the pieces of aluminium came to be in the tomb.\n\nBeachcombing need only add that the three end by suggesting that the aluminium had been included with the other belt fragments as a practical joke at the time of excavation, but that the joke got out of hand: memories of Anglo-Saxon Attitudes.\n\nIt is a reasonable solution and \u2018Butler, Glidewell and Pritchard, 1986\u2019 is now the conventional answer to the problem of the Nanjing Belt in west and east.\n\nBeachcombing is a natural sceptic where aluminium before its time is on offer. But he is left slightly cold by the methodology in the St Andrews article. After all, the authors seem to go backwards, proving first that something cannot have been done\u2026 Still unless there is a way to prove the age of aluminium in the laboratory perhaps they had no other way to approach the problem.\n\nBeach will round off with William R. Corliss on the belt in 2003 for Corliss introduces one later Chinese attempt to explain the belt as a genuine artifact (249):\n\n&gt; \u2018Assuming no hoax, it would appear that the Chinese had somehow isolated aluminum from its ores 1,500 years before the Europeans. Much has been made of the so-called Nanjing belt. No vague tale from antiquity, the tomb and belt were thoroughly studied by modern archaeologist and chemists. The latter vouched for the existence of aluminum. A hoax was deemed highly improbable. Where, then, did the aluminum come from? Two possibilities seem in play: (1) The Chinese metallurgists of the Jin Dynasty, who had high temperature furnaces, accidentally hit upon one of several ways to chemically win aluminum from one of its several ones. (2) Contradicting the encyclopaedias [i.e. aluminium not found in an isolated form], Chinese geologists reported in 1985 that they had found grains of native aluminum in Guizhou Province. Could the Jin Dynasty metallurgists have collected enough of these grains to make the aluminum sections of the Nanjing belt? Did they hammer the grains together or perhaps melt them. The melting point of pure aluminum is only 1220 f. This temperature might not been out of reach 1,500 years ago.\u2019\n\nBeachcombing is always on the look out for \u301014\u2020wrong time\u3011 objects: drbeachcombing AT yahoo DOT com\n\n***\n\n12 July 2011: Marcy writes in to say, \u2018If temperatures of only 1220 F are required to extract aluminum from soil, then the Chinese should be ruling the world. \u00a0 Their porcelains have been fired to temperatures well over 2500 F for millenia. \u00a0The \u201cstandard\u201d among American potters is currently (2011) called \u2018cone 6\u2032. \u00a0 Cone six is attained between 2230 and 2250 Fahrenheit. \u00a0Even in the USA some dedicated potters fire to cone 10 and cone 13. \u00a0 That covers 2380 to 2455 Fahrenheit. \u00a0There must be a strong interaction between pottery and metallurgy.\u2019 Thanks Marcy!\n\n### Related posts\n\n  1. \u301015\u2020An Elephant Invades Italy in 1936\u3011\n  2. \u301016\u2020Druidic Ravens at the Tower of London?\u3011\n  3. \u301017\u2020Total Eclipse\u3011\n  4. \u301018\u2020Ancient Beliefs in Modern Egypt\u3011\n  5. \u301019\u2020Oaks: Sacrificial and Otherwise\u3011\n\nTags:\u301020\u2020China\u3011, \u301021\u2020Jin Dynasty\u3011, \u301022\u2020Nanjing Belt\u3011, \u301023\u2020St Andrews\u3011, \u301024\u2020William Corliss\u3011, \u301025\u2020Wrong Time\u3011\n\n  * ## Tags\n\n\u301032\u2020Africa\u3011 \u301033\u2020Britain\u3011 \u301034\u2020Capital Punishment\u3011 \u301020\u2020China\u3011 \u301035\u2020Christianity\u3011 \u301036\u2020Cobblers\u3011 \u301037\u2020Cornwall\u3011 \u301038\u2020Crime\u3011 \u301039\u2020Cryptozoology\u3011 \u301040\u2020Egypt\u3011 \u301041\u2020Fairies\u3011 \u301042\u2020Flight\u3011 \u301043\u2020Florence\u3011 \u301044\u2020Folklore\u3011 \u301045\u2020Food\u3011 \u301046\u2020Forteana\u3011 \u301047\u2020France\u3011 \u301048\u2020Germany\u3011 \u301049\u2020Ghosts\u3011 \u301050\u2020Image\u3011 \u301051\u2020India\u3011 \u301052\u2020Ireland\u3011 \u301053\u2020Italy\u3011 \u301054\u2020Japan\u3011 \u301055\u2020Lancashire\u3011 \u301056\u2020London\u3011 \u301057\u2020Medicine\u3011 \u301058\u2020Mermaids\u3011 \u301059\u2020Review\u3011 \u301060\u2020Romans\u3011 \u301061\u2020Scotland\u3011 \u301062\u2020Soviet Union\u3011 \u301063\u2020Spain\u3011 \u301064\u2020Urban Legends\u3011 \u301065\u2020US\u3011 \u301066\u2020Victorians\u3011 \u301067\u2020Wales\u3011 \u301068\u2020Weird Wars\u3011 \u301069\u2020WIBT\u3011 \u301070\u2020Witchcraft\u3011 \u301071\u2020Wrong Place\u3011 \u301025\u2020Wrong Time\u3011 \u301072\u2020WtH\u3011 \u301073\u2020WW1\u3011 \u301074\u2020WW2\u3011\n\n  *  \n\n## Recent Posts\n\n    * \u301075\u2020Early Modern Fairy Sex Spell\u3011 \n    * \u301076\u2020Karl Banse: The Man Who Made the Case for Mermaids\u3011 \n    * \u301077\u2020The Wood Diva\u3011 \n    * \u301078\u2020The Dancing Fairies of Sennen Cove:\u3011 \n    * \u301079\u2020The Modern Western Ghost and Its Zombie Origins\u3011 \n    * \u301080\u2020Horse Spirits: Colt-Pixy or Pixy-Colt?\u3011 \n    * \u301081\u2020The When of Levitation in the West\u3011 \n    * \u301082\u2020The Fairy Census: End Game\u3011 \n    * \u301083\u2020Immortals and Itinerants\u3011 \n    * \u301084\u2020Devil at the Wedding (Ritual)\u3011 \n  * ## Categories\n\n    * \u301085\u2020Actualite\u3011 (187) \n    * \u30106\u2020Ancient\u3011 (371) \n    * \u301086\u2020Beachcombed\u3011 (97) \n    * \u30107\u2020Contemporary\u3011 (905) \n    * \u30102\u2020Historical Pictures\u3011 (838) \n    * \u301087\u2020History Roundups\u3011 (19) \n    * \u301088\u2020Medieval\u3011 (600) \n    * \u301089\u2020Modern\u3011 (1,590) \n    * \u30103\u2020New History Books\u3011 (124) \n    * \u301090\u2020Prehistoric\u3011 (51) \n  *", "title": "The Nanjing Belt - Beachcombing&#x27;s Bizarre History Blog", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "The Nanjing Belt - Beachcombing&#x27;s Bizarre History Blog", "url": "http://www.strangehistory.net/2011/07/09/the-nanjing-belt/", "text": "\nThe belt included \u2018about\u2019 (?) twenty pieces of metal \u2013 which had presumably been attached to the now rotted leather \u2013 and four of these were made of almost pure \u301012\u2020aluminium\u2020www.dgs.ca.gov\u3011. Aluminium it will be remembered does not appear alone in nature. It took Europeans till the early nineteenth century to understand how to isolate this useful substance and even then the aluminium that issued was far from pure.\n\nChinese historians were, understandably, bemused and something of a civil war broke out, not helped by the fact that the Cultural Revolution was on the horizon. If there was a resolution though before Mao\u2019s guillotine came down it was that four pieces were, indeed, aluminium. The problem then was not metallurgical but rather archaeological: were they Jin Dynasty \u301013\u2020relics\u2020www.azed.gov\u3011 or had they been placed in the tomb in the nineteenth or twentieth centuries? If genuine, it goes without saying that you would need a merchant cash advance and possibly your life savings multiplied by three to get a sniff at these objects in an auction house.\n\nThis question was taken up in the west by three scholars \u2013 Butler, Glidewell and Pritchard \u2013 at St Andrew\u2019s University who looked at the question in\u00a0 \u2018Aluminium Objects from a Jin Dynasty Tomb \u2013 Can They Be Authentic?\u2019 Interdisciplinary Science Reviews 11 (1986), 88-94.\n\nThe abstract sums up their work nicely:\n\n&gt; Pieces of aluminium, supposedly parts of a set of belt ornaments, were found in a Jin dynasty (AD 265\u2013420) tomb during excavations in the 1950s. The authenticity of these finds was questioned at the time in view of the technology required to isolate aluminium from its ore. In this review the archaeological and analytical evidence is reconsidered, but the matter remains unsettled, as it is known, from experimental evidence, that aluminium alloys can be prepared by the carbon reduction of alumina. Examination of the thermodynamic data for this process in terms of Ellingham diagrams demonstrates unequivocally that the temperature required for this process is greatly in excess of that possible with Jin dynasty technology, and so the finds cannot be authentic. However, it is quite possible that metallic objects containing small quantities of aluminium could have been produced in China at that time. The review ends with some speculation on how the pieces of aluminium came to be in the tomb.\n\nBeachcombing need only add that the three end by suggesting that the aluminium had been included with the other belt fragments as a practical joke at the time of excavation, but that the joke got out of hand: memories of Anglo-Saxon Attitudes.\n\nIt is a reasonable solution and \u2018Butler, Glidewell and Pritchard, 1986\u2019 is now the conventional answer to the problem of the Nanjing Belt in west and east.\n\nBeachcombing is a natural sceptic where aluminium before its time is on offer. But he is left slightly cold by the methodology in the St Andrews article. After all, the authors seem to go backwards, proving first that something cannot have been done\u2026 Still unless there is a way to prove the age of aluminium in the laboratory perhaps they had no other way to approach the problem.\n\nBeach will round off with William R. Corliss on the belt in 2003 for Corliss introduces one later Chinese attempt to explain the belt as a genuine artifact (249):\n\n&gt; \u2018Assuming no hoax, it would appear that the Chinese had somehow isolated aluminum from its ores 1,500 years before the Europeans. Much has been made of the so-called Nanjing belt. No vague tale from antiquity, the tomb and belt were thoroughly studied by modern archaeologist and chemists. The latter vouched for the existence of aluminum. A hoax was deemed highly improbable. Where, then, did the aluminum come from? Two possibilities seem in play: (1) The Chinese metallurgists of the Jin Dynasty, who had high temperature furnaces, accidentally hit upon one of several ways to chemically win aluminum from one of its several ones. (2) Contradicting the encyclopaedias [i.e. aluminium not found in an isolated form], Chinese geologists reported in 1985 that they had found grains of native aluminum in Guizhou Province. Could the Jin Dynasty metallurgists have collected enough of these grains to make the aluminum sections of the Nanjing belt? Did they hammer the grains together or perhaps melt them. The melting point of pure aluminum is only 1220 f. This temperature might not been out of reach 1,500 years ago.\u2019\n\nBeachcombing is always on the look out for \u301014\u2020wrong time\u3011 objects: drbeachcombing AT yahoo DOT com\n\n***\n\n12 July 2011: Marcy writes in to say, \u2018If temperatures of only 1220 F are required to extract aluminum from soil, then the Chinese should be ruling the world. \u00a0 Their porcelains have been fired to temperatures well over 2500 F for millenia. \u00a0The \u201cstandard\u201d among American potters is currently (2011) called \u2018cone 6\u2032. \u00a0 Cone six is attained between 2230 and 2250 Fahrenheit. \u00a0Even in the USA some dedicated potters fire to cone 10 and cone 13. \u00a0 That covers 2380 to 2455 Fahrenheit. \u00a0There must be a strong interaction between pottery and metallurgy.\u2019 Thanks Marcy!\n\n### Related posts\n\n  1. \u301015\u2020An Elephant Invades Italy in 1936\u3011\n  2. \u301016\u2020Druidic Ravens at the Tower of London?\u3011\n  3. \u301017\u2020Total Eclipse\u3011\n  4. \u301018\u2020Ancient Beliefs in Modern Egypt\u3011\n  5. \u301019\u2020Oaks: Sacrificial and Otherwise\u3011\n\nTags:\u301020\u2020China\u3011, \u301021\u2020Jin Dynasty\u3011, \u301022\u2020Nanjing Belt\u3011, \u301023\u2020St Andrews\u3011, \u301024\u2020William Corliss\u3011, \u301025\u2020Wrong Time\u3011\n\n  * ## Categories\n\n    * \u301085\u2020Actualite\u3011 (187) \n    * \u30106\u2020Ancient\u3011 (371) \n    * \u301086\u2020Beachcombed\u3011 (97) \n    * \u30107\u2020Contemporary\u3011 (905) \n    * \u30102\u2020Historical Pictures\u3011 (838) \n    * \u301087\u2020History Roundups\u3011 (19) \n    * \u301088\u2020Medieval\u3011 (600) \n    * \u301089\u2020Modern\u3011 (1,590) \n    * \u30103\u2020New History Books\u3011 (124) \n    * \u301090\u2020Prehistoric\u3011 (51) \n  *", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[0, 1, 2]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "63fe83c7-f808-470e-b5db-27f70fd020d2", "request_id": "8d7c5471fee84c6a-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "63fe83c7-f808-470e-b5db-27f70fd020d2", "children": ["b20bd8d0-847a-4755-848f-31d7e821df4f"]}, "b20bd8d0-847a-4755-848f-31d7e821df4f": { "message": { "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1729797703.004566, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["The artifact you are referring to is known as the **Nanjing Belt**, discovered in a Jin Dynasty tomb in China, which has sparked significant controversy due to its inclusion of **aluminum** components. This belt was found in the tomb of Zhou Chu, a notable Jin Dynasty general, during the 1950s. The discovery was puzzling because aluminum is notoriously difficult to produce and isolate, requiring advanced technology that wasn\u2019t available until the 19th century.\n\nTests conducted on the belt fragments in the 1950s and 1960s revealed that some of the metal pieces were composed of almost pure aluminum. This finding created shockwaves in the scientific community, as aluminum production requires highly advanced metallurgical techniques that were unknown at the time of the Jin Dynasty (3rd century AD). Some theories suggest that the aluminum might have been introduced into the tomb later, possibly by grave robbers, while others speculate about unknown ancient methods of aluminum extraction. There are even fringe theories that suggest extraterrestrial intervention or lost ancient technologies.\n\nDespite multiple analyses, the origin and authenticity of the aluminum in the belt remain unresolved, with scholars divided on whether it is a genuine ancient artifact or a more modern intrusion into the tomb\u301012\u2020source\u3011\u301013\u2020source\u3011."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true
, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [{"start_ix": 1311, "end_ix": 1322, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "The Enigma of the Nanjing Belt: How Could this Out of Place Artifact Exist? | Ancient Origins", "url": "https://www.ancient-origins.net/artifacts-ancient-technology/nanjing-belt-0018546", "text": "\n  * \u301074\u2020The Legacy of Armenia: Trade, Metallurgy, and Forging of Precious Metals of the Ancient World\u3011\n  * \u301075\u2020Bronze Urartian Belt Proves Kingdom Extended Much Further North\u3011\n\n[Image 18: Aluminium artifact found in a 3rd century Chinese tomb. (Soul-guidance)]\n\nAluminium artifact found in a 3rd century Chinese tomb. (\u301076\u2020Soul-guidance\u2020www.soul-guidance.com\u3011)\n\n## A Discovery That Defied Common Knowledge\n\nSoon after the stunning discovery, the Chinese scientific circles were stirred. Thorough analysis was required of all the metallic pieces discovered. The first tests were conducted by Nanjing University, and the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and they found that the tested pieces were an alloy containing mostly aluminum.\n\nSuch a claim caused a big shock, as everyone knew that aluminum is very difficult to isolate from bauxite, as a pure metal, without using a lot of electric power. Nevertheless, further tests were conducted, on other pieces as well, revealing that not all of them were from aluminum. Others were made from an alloy that contained mostly \u301077\u2020silver\u3011.\n\nBetween 1958 and 1959, the third round of tests was conducted at Qinghua University, where it was finally firmly concluded that the primary metal in the alloy was aluminum, with other fragments made from silver alloy.\n\nFrom this point on, there were other studies over the decades - many of which tried to change the narrative that was established early on. One theory stated that the aluminum belt parts were irregularly shaped, and could have been parts of modern aluminum tools that were left by potential grave robbers before the discovery was made. While it is possible that grave robbers entered the grave before the very first arrival of the archaeological team, it is not certain that anything of the sort occurred, or that they dropped aluminum fragments.\n\nSome sources claim that there were other similar belt buckles amongst other ancient Chinese relics, containing parts made from aluminum. They were never studied, however, and their presence remains unconfirmed. Either way, the Nanjing Belt left a deep whirlpool in the Chinese and global scholarly circles. It provided an enigma that was never fully resolved.\n\n  * \u301078\u2020More than Metal: Amazing Historical Suits of Armor\u3011\n  * \u301079\u2020UFO Wreckage? Ancient Metal Object Found in Romania Has Unexplained Origins\u3011\n\n## The Tomb Veiled in Mystery\n\nSadly, there isn\u2019t much more that is known about the Nanjing Belt or the discovery of the ancient hero\u2019s tomb. Popular sources are exceptionally vague on this topic - perhaps for a reason? Officially, the tomb of Zhou Chu is not mentioned. The mentions of this 1952 discovery are reserved only to the fringes of the online scholarly communities, and we cannot say why.\n\nPopularly, the writer Erich von D\u00e4niken, in his famed work \u201cChariots of the Gods\u201d, wrote of this discovery and claimed that the traces of aluminum alloy are a clear proof of \u301080\u2020ancient aliens\u3011 visiting Earth and sharing deep knowledge with ancient civilizations.\n\nCould such a thing be true? We do not know for certain. Could it, on the other hand, be possible that the ancient Chinese found a way to create an aluminum alloy through methods lost to history and the knowledge of man? If it is so, then there truly are deeper secrets hiding in the world\u2019s history.\n\nTop image: Left, ancient alchemy painting. Right, The artifact known as the \u2018Nanjing Belt\u2019 seems to be proof of the existence of aluminum in early China. Source: Left; \u301081\u2020primopiano\u2020as2.ftcdn.net\u3011/Adobe Stock Right; \u301076\u2020Soul-guidance\u2020www.soul-guidance.com\u3011\n\nBy \u301065\u2020Aleksa Vu\u010dkovi\u0107\u3011\n\n## References\n\nLloyd, E. 2017. Aluminum Was Used At Least 7,000 Years Ago \u2013 Long Before the Metal\u2019s Official Invention In 1825. Science and Civilization in China: Volume 5. Chemistry and Chemical Technology. University of Pennsylvania.\n\n  * \n\nSection:\u00a0\n\n\u301018\u2020Artifacts\u3011\n\n\u301049\u2020Ancient Technology\u3011\n\n\u301084\u2020News\u3011\n\nTags:\u00a0\n\n\u301085\u2020oopart\u3011\n\n\u301086\u2020belt\u3011\n\n\u301087\u2020China\u3011\n\n\u301088\u2020alchemy\u3011\n\n\u301089\u2020metallurgy\u3011\n\n\u301090\u2020aluminum\u3011\n\n[Image 19: Aleksa Vu\u010dkovi\u0107&#x27;s picture]\n\n### Aleksa\n\nI am a published author of over ten historical fiction novels, and I specialize in Slavic linguistics. Source: Author provided]\n\n2 November, 2022 - 13:52 \u301091\u2020Cliff Dunning\u3011\n\n## \u301092\u2020Examining Out-of-Place Stone Figures from the Forgotten City of Oxkintok\u3011\n\nI\u2019ve had an affinity for the Maya civilization for almost 30 years, and between working with native elders, vacations, and leading tour group visits to Mexico, I can vouch for the mystical nature of...\n\n  * \u301093\u2020Read Later\u3011\u00a0\n  * \u301092\u2020Read more about Examining Out-of-Place Stone Figures from the Forgotten City of Oxkintok\u3011\n\n[Image 21: Library in Stone: The Ica Stones of Professor Cabrera \u2013 Part I]\n\n16 February, 2022 - 00:54 \u301094\u2020WalterJoergLangbein\u3011\n\n## \u301095\u2020Library in Stone: The Ica Stones of Professor Cabrera \u2013 Part I\u3011\n\nIn 1961, the Rio Ica burst its banks and flooded parts of the Ocucaje Desert. Was an earthquake responsible for the flood? When the water had retreated, the local farmers inspected the damage. Their...\n\n  * \u301096\u2020Read Later\u3011\u00a0\n  * \u301095\u2020Read more about Library in Stone: The Ica Stones of Professor Cabrera \u2013 Part I\u3011\n\n[Image 22: The so-called Sivatherium of Kish (Field Museum of Natural History/Edwin H. Colbert) compared to a modern representation of a Sivatherium in the Warsaw Museum of Evolution. (Shalom/CC BY-SA 3.0)]\n\n6 February, 2022 - 14:00 \u301065\u2020Aleksa Vu\u010dkovi\u0107\u3011\n\n## \u301097\u2020The Sivatherium of Kish: Did Sumerians Tame a Prehistoric Giraffe?\u3011\n\nThe world is big. Even in this modern day and age, we still don\u2019t have a clue about what lurks in the remote corners of this planet. The oceans, vast and enigmatic, have only been partially explored...\n\n  * \u301098\u2020Read Later\u3011\u00a0\n  * \u301097\u2020Read more about The Sivatherium of Kish: Did Sumerians Tame a Prehistoric Giraffe?\u3011\n\n[Image 23: The Swiss ring watch found by Chinese archaeologists within a Ming Dynasty tomb. Source: EuroPics]\n\n21 January, 2022 - 14:01 \u301099\u2020lizleafloor\u3011\n\n## \u3010100\u2020Bizarre Finding of a Swiss Ring Watch in a Sealed Ming Dynasty Tomb\u3011\n\nAn aura of mystery continues to surround the excavation of a curious artifact which was recovered from the depths of an ancient tomb in China. When archaeologists reportedly recovered a modern-...\n\n  * \u3010101\u2020Read Later\u3011\u00a0\n  * \u3010100\u2020Read more about Bizarre Finding of a Swiss Ring Watch in a Sealed Ming Dynasty Tomb\u3011\n\n[Image 24: Latter Day Forgeries: The Hoax of the Kinderhook Plates ]\n\n1 August, 2021 - 14:56 \u3010102\u2020Kurt Readman\u3011\n\n## \u3010103\u2020Latter Day Forgeries: The Hoax of the Kinderhook Plates \u3011\n\nIn the 19th century, golden plates were discovered in Kinderhook in the United States. They were meant to reveal an ancient pharaoh\u2019s lineage, but all was not as it seemed. The first week in May 1843...\n\n  * \u3010104\u2020Read Later\u3011\u00a0\n  * \u3010103\u2020Read more about Latter Day Forgeries: The Hoax of the Kinderhook Plates \u3011\n\n[Image 25: The Disc of Sabu: Ancient Egyptian Water Pump or Alien Hyperdrive?]\n\n31 July, 2021 - 22:57 \u301065\u2020Aleksa Vu\u010dkovi\u0107\u3011\n\n## \u3010105\u2020The Disc of Sabu: Ancient Egyptian Water Pump or Alien Hyperdrive?\u3011\n\nThere is no doubt that the Ancient Egyptian civilization is filled with wonders and mysteries beyond our comprehension. An exceptionally old culture that reaches far back to the early dawn of man\u2019s...\n\n  * \u3010106\u2020Read Later\u3011\u00a0\n  * \u3010105\u2020Read more about The Disc of Sabu: Ancient Egyptian Water Pump or Alien Hyperdrive?\u3011\n\n[Image 26]\n\n[Image 27]\n\n\u3010107\u2020 \u2020bit.ly\u3011 \n\n[Image 28] \n\nI agree to receiving emails  Read terms \n\n  By subscribing to Ancient-Orgins.net,", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 12, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}, {"start_ix": 1322, "end_ix": 1333, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "The Nanjing Belt - Beachcombing&#x27;s Bizarre History Blog", "url": "http://www.strangehistory.net/2011/07/09/the-nanjing-belt/", "text": "\nThe belt included \u2018about\u2019 (?) twenty pieces of metal \u2013 which had presumably been attached to the now rotted leather \u2013 and four of these were made of almost pure \u301012\u2020aluminium\u2020www.dgs.ca.gov\u3011. Aluminium it will be remembered does not appear alone in nature. It took Europeans till the early nineteenth century to understand how to isolate this useful substance and even then the aluminium that issued was far from pure.\n\nChinese historians were, understandably, bemused and something of a civil war broke out, not helped by the fact that the Cultural Revolution was on the horizon. If there was a resolution though before Mao\u2019s guillotine came down it was that four pieces were, indeed, aluminium. The problem then was not metallurgical but rather archaeological: were they Jin Dynasty \u301013\u2020relics\u2020www.azed.gov\u3011 or had they been placed in the tomb in the nineteenth or twentieth centuries? If genuine, it goes without saying that you would need a merchant cash advance and possibly your life savings multiplied by three to get a sniff at these objects in an auction house.\n\nThis question was taken up in the west by three scholars \u2013 Butler, Glidewell and Pritchard \u2013 at St Andrew\u2019s University who looked at the question in\u00a0 \u2018Aluminium Objects from a Jin Dynasty Tomb \u2013 Can They Be Authentic?\u2019 Interdisciplinary Science Reviews 11 (1986), 88-94.\n\nThe abstract sums up their work nicely:\n\n&gt; Pieces of aluminium, supposedly parts of a set of belt ornaments, were found in a Jin dynasty (AD 265\u2013420) tomb during excavations in the 1950s. The authenticity of these finds was questioned at the time in view of the technology required to isolate aluminium from its ore. In this review the archaeological and analytical evidence is reconsidered, but the matter remains unsettled, as it is known, from experimental evidence, that aluminium alloys can be prepared by the carbon reduction of alumina. Examination of the thermodynamic data for this process in terms of Ellingham diagrams demonstrates unequivocally that the temperature required for this process is greatly in excess of that possible with Jin dynasty technology, and so the finds cannot be authentic. However, it is quite possible that metallic objects containing small quantities of aluminium could have been produced in China at that time. The review ends with some speculation on how the pieces of aluminium came to be in the tomb.\n\nBeachcombing need only add that the three end by suggesting that the aluminium had been included with the other belt fragments as a practical joke at the time of excavation, but that the joke got out of hand: memories of Anglo-Saxon Attitudes.\n\nIt is a reasonable solution and \u2018Butler, Glidewell and Pritchard, 1986\u2019 is now the conventional answer to the problem of the Nanjing Belt in west and east.\n\nBeachcombing is a natural sceptic where aluminium before its time is on offer. But he is left slightly cold by the methodology in the St Andrews article. After all, the authors seem to go backwards, proving first that something cannot have been done\u2026 Still unless there is a way to prove the age of aluminium in the laboratory perhaps they had no other way to approach the problem.\n\nBeach will round off with William R. Corliss on the belt in 2003 for Corliss introduces one later Chinese attempt to explain the belt as a genuine artifact (249):\n\n&gt; \u2018Assuming no hoax, it would appear that the Chinese had somehow isolated aluminum from its ores 1,500 years before the Europeans. Much has been made of the so-called Nanjing belt. No vague tale from antiquity, the tomb and belt were thoroughly studied by modern archaeologist and chemists. The latter vouched for the existence of aluminum. A hoax was deemed highly improbable. Where, then, did the aluminum come from? Two possibilities seem in play: (1) The Chinese metallurgists of the Jin Dynasty, who had high temperature furnaces, accidentally hit upon one of several ways to chemically win aluminum from one of its several ones. (2) Contradicting the encyclopaedias [i.e. aluminium not found in an isolated form], Chinese geologists reported in 1985 that they had found grains of native aluminum in Guizhou Province. Could the Jin Dynasty metallurgists have collected enough of these grains to make the aluminum sections of the Nanjing belt? Did they hammer the grains together or perhaps melt them. The melting point of pure aluminum is only 1220 f. This temperature might not been out of reach 1,500 years ago.\u2019\n\nBeachcombing is always on the look out for \u301014\u2020wrong time\u3011 objects: drbeachcombing AT yahoo DOT com\n\n***\n\n12 July 2011: Marcy writes in to say, \u2018If temperatures of only 1220 F are required to extract aluminum from soil, then the Chinese should be ruling the world. \u00a0 Their porcelains have been fired to temperatures well over 2500 F for millenia. \u00a0The \u201cstandard\u201d among American potters is currently (2011) called \u2018cone 6\u2032. \u00a0 Cone six is attained between 2230 and 2250 Fahrenheit. \u00a0Even in the USA some dedicated potters fire to cone 10 and cone 13. \u00a0 That covers 2380 to 2455 Fahrenheit. \u00a0There must be a strong interaction between pottery and metallurgy.\u2019 Thanks Marcy!\n\n### Related posts\n\n  1. \u301015\u2020An Elephant Invades Italy in 1936\u3011\n  2. \u301016\u2020Druidic Ravens at the Tower of London?\u3011\n  3. \u301017\u2020Total Eclipse\u3011\n  4. \u301018\u2020Ancient Beliefs in Modern Egypt\u3011\n  5. \u301019\u2020Oaks: Sacrificial and Otherwise\u3011\n\nTags:\u301020\u2020China\u3011, \u301021\u2020Jin Dynasty\u3011, \u301022\u2020Nanjing Belt\u3011, \u301023\u2020St Andrews\u3011, \u301024\u2020William Corliss\u3011, \u301025\u2020Wrong Time\u3011\n\n  * ## Categories\n\n    * \u301085\u2020Actualite\u3011 (187) \n    * \u30106\u2020Ancient\u3011 (371) \n    * \u301086\u2020Beachcombed\u3011 (97) \n    * \u30107\u2020Contemporary\u3011 (905) \n    * \u30102\u2020Historical Pictures\u3011 (838) \n    * \u301087\u2020History Roundups\u3011 (19) \n    * \u301088\u2020Medieval\u3011 (600) \n    * \u301089\u2020Modern\u3011 (1,590) \n    * \u30103\u2020New History Books\u3011 (124) \n    * \u301090\u2020Prehistoric\u3011 (51) \n  *", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 13, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}], "content_references": [{"matched_text": "\u301012\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1311, "end_idx": 1322, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "The Enigma of the Nanjing Belt: How Could this Out of Place Artifact Exist? | Ancient Origins", "url": "https://www.ancient-origins.net/artifacts-ancient-technology/nanjing-belt-0018546", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\n  * \u301074\u2020The Legacy of Armenia: Trade, Metallurgy, and Forging of Precious Metals of the Ancient World\u3011\n  * \u301075\u2020Bronze Urartian Belt Proves Kingdom Extended Much Further North\u3011\n\n[Image 18: Aluminium artifact found in a 3rd century Chinese tomb. (Soul-guidance)]\n\nAluminium artifact found in a 3rd century Chinese tomb. (\u301076\u2020Soul-guidance\u2020www.soul-guidance.com\u3011)\n\n## A Discovery That Defied Common Knowledge\n\nSoon after the stunning discovery, the Chinese scientific circles were stirred. Thorough analysis was required of all the metallic pieces discovered. The first tests were conducted by Nanjing University, and the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and they found that the tested pieces were an alloy containing mostly aluminum.\n\nSuch a claim caused a big shock, as everyone knew that aluminum is very difficult to isolate from bauxite, as a pure metal, without using a lot of electric power. Nevertheless, further tests were conducted, on other pieces as well, revealing that not all of them were from aluminum. Others were made from an alloy that contained mostly \u301077\u2020silver\u3011.\n\nBetween 1958 and 1959, the third round of tests was conducted at Qinghua University, where it was finally firmly concluded that the primary metal in the alloy was aluminum, with other fragments made from silver alloy.\n\nFrom this point on, there were other studies over the decades - many of which tried to change the narrative that was established early on. One theory stated that the aluminum belt parts were irregularly shaped, and could have been parts of modern aluminum tools that were left by potential grave robbers before the discovery was made. While it is possible that grave robbers entered the grave before the very first arrival of the archaeological team, it is not certain that anything of the sort occurred, or that they dropped aluminum fragments.\n\nSome sources claim that there were other similar belt buckles amongst other ancient Chinese relics, containing parts made from aluminum. They were never studied, however, and their presence remains unconfirmed. Either way, the Nanjing Belt left a deep whirlpool in the Chinese and global scholarly circles. It provided an enigma that was never fully resolved.\n\n  * \u301078\u2020More than Metal: Amazing Historical Suits of Armor\u3011\n  * \u301079\u2020UFO Wreckage? Ancient Metal Object Found in Romania Has Unexplained Origins\u3011\n\n## The Tomb Veiled in Mystery\n\nSadly, there isn\u2019t much more that is known about the Nanjing Belt or the discovery of the ancient hero\u2019s tomb. Popular sources are exceptionally vague on this topic - perhaps for a reason? Officially, the tomb of Zhou Chu is not mentioned. The mentions of this 1952 discovery are reserved only to the fringes of the online scholarly communities, and we cannot say why.\n\nPopularly, the writer Erich von D\u00e4niken, in his famed work \u201cChariots of the Gods\u201d, wrote of this discovery and claimed that the traces of aluminum alloy are a clear proof of \u301080\u2020ancient aliens\u3011 visiting Earth and sharing deep knowledge with ancient civilizations.\n\nCould such a thing be true? We do not know for certain. Could it, on the other hand, be possible that the ancient Chinese found a way to create an aluminum alloy through methods lost to history and the knowledge of man? If it is so, then there truly are deeper secrets hiding in the world\u2019s history.\n\nTop image: Left, ancient alchemy painting. Right, The artifact known as the \u2018Nanjing Belt\u2019 seems to be proof of the existence of aluminum in early China. Source: Left; \u301081\u2020primopiano\u2020as2.ftcdn.net\u3011/Adobe Stock Right; \u301076\u2020Soul-guidance\u2020www.soul-guidance.com\u3011\n\nBy \u301065\u2020Aleksa Vu\u010dkovi\u0107\u3011\n\n## References\n\nLloyd, E. 2017. An exceptionally old culture that reaches far back to the early dawn of man\u2019s...\n\n  * \u3010106\u2020Read Later\u3011\u00a0\n  * \u3010105\u2020Read more about The Disc of Sabu: Ancient Egyptian Water Pump or Alien Hyperdrive?\u3011\n\n[Image 26]\n\n[Image 27]\n\n\u3010107\u2020 \u2020bit.ly\u3011 \n\n[Image 28] \n\nI agree to receiving emails  Read terms \n\n  By subscribing to Ancient-Orgins.net,"}, {"matched_text": "\u301013\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1322, "end_idx": 1333, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "The Nanjing Belt - Beachcombing&#x27;s Bizarre History Blog", "url": "http://www.strangehistory.net/2011/07/09/the-nanjing-belt/", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\nThe belt included \u2018about\u2019 (?) twenty pieces of metal \u2013 which had presumably been attached to the now rotted leather \u2013 and four of these were made of almost pure \u301012\u2020aluminium\u2020www.dgs.ca.gov\u3011. Aluminium it will be remembered does not appear alone in nature. It took Europeans till the early nineteenth century to understand how to isolate this useful substance and even then the aluminium that issued was far from pure.\n\nChinese historians were, understandably, bemused and something of a civil war broke out, not helped by the fact that the Cultural Revolution was on the horizon. If there was a resolution though before Mao\u2019s guillotine came down it was that four pieces were, indeed, aluminium. The problem then was not metallurgical but rather archaeological: were they Jin Dynasty \u301013\u2020relics\u2020www.azed.gov\u3011 or had they been placed in the tomb in the nineteenth or twentieth centuries? If genuine, it goes without saying that you would need a merchant cash advance and possibly your life savings multiplied by three to get a sniff at these objects in an auction house.\n\nThis question was taken up in the west by three scholars \u2013 Butler, Glidewell and Pritchard \u2013 at St Andrew\u2019s University who looked at the question in\u00a0 \u2018Aluminium Objects from a Jin Dynasty Tomb \u2013 Can They Be Authentic?\u2019 Interdisciplinary Science Reviews 11 (1986), 88-94.\n\nThe abstract sums up their work nicely:\n\n&gt; Pieces of aluminium, supposedly parts of a set of belt ornaments, were found in a Jin dynasty (AD 265\u2013420) tomb during excavations in the 1950s. The authenticity of these finds was questioned at the time in view of the technology required to isolate aluminium from its ore. In this review the archaeological and analytical evidence is reconsidered, but the matter remains unsettled, as it is known, from experimental evidence, that aluminium alloys can be prepared by the carbon reduction of alumina. Examination of the thermodynamic data for this process in terms of Ellingham diagrams demonstrates unequivocally that the temperature required for this process is greatly in excess of that possible with Jin dynasty technology, and so the finds cannot be authentic. However, it is quite possible that metallic objects containing small quantities of aluminium could have been produced in China at that time. The review ends with some speculation on how the pieces of aluminium came to be in the tomb.\n\nBeachcombing need only add that the three end by suggesting that the aluminium had been included with the other belt fragments as a practical joke at the time of excavation, but that the joke got out of hand: memories of Anglo-Saxon Attitudes.\n\nIt is a reasonable solution and \u2018Butler, Glidewell and Pritchard, 1986\u2019 is now the conventional answer to the problem of the Nanjing Belt in west and east.\n\nBeachcombing is a natural sceptic where aluminium before its time is on offer. But he is left slightly cold by the methodology in the St Andrews article. After all, the authors seem to go backwards, proving first that something cannot have been done\u2026 Still unless there is a way to prove the age of aluminium in the laboratory perhaps they had no other way to approach the problem.\n\nBeach will round off with William R. Corliss on the belt in 2003 for Corliss introduces one later Chinese attempt to explain the belt as a genuine artifact (249):\n\n&gt; \u2018Assuming no hoax, it would appear that the Chinese had somehow isolated aluminum from its ores 1,500 years before the Europeans. Much has been made of the so-called Nanjing belt. No vague tale from antiquity, the tomb and belt were thoroughly studied by modern archaeologist and chemists. The latter vouched for the existence of aluminum. A hoax was deemed highly improbable. Where, then, did the aluminum come from? Two possibilities seem in play: (1) The Chinese metallurgists of the Jin Dynasty, who had high temperature furnaces, accidentally hit upon one of several ways to chemically win aluminum from one of its several ones. (2) Contradicting the encyclopaedias [i.e. aluminium not found in an isolated form], Chinese geologists reported in 1985 that they had found grains of native aluminum in Guizhou Province. Could the Jin Dynasty metallurgists have collected enough of these grains to make the aluminum sections of the Nanjing belt? Did they hammer the grains together or perhaps melt them. The melting point of pure aluminum is only 1220 f. This temperature might not been out of reach 1,500 years ago.\u2019\n\nBeachcombing is always on the look out for \u301014\u2020wrong time\u3011 objects: drbeachcombing AT yahoo DOT com\n\n***\n\n12 July 2011: Marcy writes in to say, \u2018If temperatures of only 1220 F are required to extract aluminum from soil, then the Chinese should be ruling the world. \u00a0 Their porcelains have been fired to temperatures well over 2500 F for millenia. \u00a0The \u201cstandard\u201d among American potters is currently (2011) called \u2018cone 6\u2032. \u00a0 Cone six is attained between 2230 and 2250 Fahrenheit. \u00a0Even in the USA some dedicated potters fire to cone 10 and cone 13. \u00a0 That covers 2380 to 2455 Fahrenheit. \u00a0There must be a strong interaction between pottery and metallurgy.\u2019 Thanks Marcy!\n\n### Related posts\n\n  1. \u301015\u2020An Elephant Invades Italy in 1936\u3011\n  2. \u301016\u2020Druidic Ravens at the Tower of London?\u3011\n  3.
